sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kent Eisenhuth)
articles.description: Accessibility for data visualization extends well beyond web standards, at least if you’re trying to create an experience that’s actually useful. This article focuses on techniques for creating useful and accessible visualizations that extend well beyond compliance.
articles.title: How Accessibility Standards Can Empower Better Chart Visual Design

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: How to design for children aged 3–12, with insights into user behavior, considerations for parents, and practical UX guidelines.
articles.title: A Practical Guide To Designing For Children

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Preethi Sam)
articles.description: A radar chart — also commonly called a spider chart — is yet another way to visualize data and make connections. Radar charts are inherently geometric, making them both a perfect fit and fun to make with CSS, thanks to the `polygon()` function. Read along as Preethi Sam demonstrates the process and sprinkles it with a pinch of JavaScript to make a handy, reusable component.
articles.title: How To Draw Radar Charts In Web

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Geoff Graham)
articles.description: What could we learn from entry-level students in front-end web development? As seasoned professionals, you might think you’ve seen it all, but the truth is that the newcomers are asking the most intriguing questions and making connections that those of us who have spent years on the front end may have never considered.
articles.title: Frequently Heard In My Beginning Front-End Web Development Class

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Juan Diego Rodríguez)
articles.description: An overwhelming number of frameworks and tooling available today gives the impression that web development has gotten perhaps too complex. Juan Diego Rodríguez explores if web development really is that complex and, most importantly, how we can prevent it from getting even more difficult than we already perceive it to be.
articles.title: Web Development Is Getting Too Complex, And It May Be Our Fault

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: With one billion people aged 60 or older worldwide, inclusivity is more important than ever. Learn how to create digital experiences that empower independence and competence for older adults while enhancing usability for all. An upcoming part of Smart Interface Design Patterns.
articles.title: A Guide To Designing For Older Adults

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Maximillian Piras)
articles.description: As Artificial Intelligence evolves the computing paradigm, designers have an opportunity to craft more intuitive user interfaces. Maximillian Piras examines how the latest AI capabilities can reshape the future of human-computer interaction beyond conversation alone.
articles.title: When Words Cannot Describe: Designing For AI Beyond Conversational Interfaces

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: With February just around the corner, how about a little inspiration boost? We might have one for you: desktop wallpapers created with love by the community for the community. Enjoy!
articles.title: 29 Days Of Inspiration (February 2024 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andy Budd)
articles.description: Most product teams commonly adopt a feature-centric mindset, finding them convenient for brainstorming, drafting requirement documents, and integrating into backlogs and ticketing systems. In this article, Andy Budd shows how fixation with features might be holding you back and how making a few small tweaks to your process could make an entire world of difference.
articles.title: The Feature Trap: Why Feature Centricity Is Harming Your Product

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Joas Pambou)
articles.description: Language models have shown impressive capabilities. But that doesn’t mean they’re without faults, as anyone who has witnessed a ChatGPT “hallucination” can attest. In this article, Joas Pambou diagnoses the symptoms that cause hallucinations and explains not only what RAG is but also different approaches for using it to solve language model limitations.
articles.title: A Simple Guide To Retrieval Augmented Generation Language Models

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Yair Even Or)
articles.description: Taking inspiration from shadows, author Yair Even Or creates the same sort of thing, only with a blurring effect in place of the shadow. Read along for a step-by-step explanation of how it comes together using a combination of masks, gradients, and the good ol’ `backdrop-filter` property.
articles.title: CSS Blurry Shimmer Effect

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Filip Paldia & Jamie Clarke)
articles.description: AI promises a major upheaval in typography, with designers finding themselves navigating both opportunities and challenges. How will it impact quality, design roles, and our use of type in the future? As we explore this new frontier, we realise that we are at a juncture as significant as Gutenberg’s press, set to redefine how we interact with text and visual communication.
articles.title: The AI Dilemma In Graphic Design: Steering Towards Excellence In Typography And Beyond

articles.title: Russian Turla Hackers Target Polish NGOs with New TinyTurla-NG Backdoor

articles.title: Ivanti Pulse Secure Found Using 11-Year-Old Linux Version and Outdated Libraries

articles.title: Chinese Hackers Using Deepfakes in Advanced Mobile Banking Malware Attacks

articles.title: Critical Exchange Server Flaw (CVE-2024-21410) Under Active Exploitation

Series 9 and Ultra 2 models cannot be imported to the US starting from 18 January

Apple will not be allowed to sell its latest watches containing blood oxygen sensors starting from Thursday, judges from the US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit ordered.…
articles.title: Ban on Apple watches with blood oxygen sensors confirmed after failed appeal

articles.description:
Aerial delivery kit doubles payloads

Alphabet's drone delivery biz, Wing, has unveiled a drone capable of carrying up to five pounds (2.26 kg) of payload, almost doubling the capacity of its existing fleet.…
articles.title: Wing, Alphabet's drone delivery unit, designs bigger bird to deliver pasta, faster

The startlingly extent to which websites and brokers hand over details of people's habits to Facebook was revealed Wednesday.…
articles.title: Study: Thousands of businesses just love handing over your info to Facebook

articles.description:
Pen-tester accessed more than 650,000 sensitive messages, and still can, at Indian outfit using Toyota SaaS

Toyota Tsusho Insurance Broker India (TTIBI), an Indo-Japanese joint insurance venture, operated a misconfigured server that exposed more than 650,000 Microsoft-hosted email messages to customers, a security researcher has found.…
articles.title: Insurance website's buggy API leaked Office 365 password and a giant email trove

articles.description:
So much for isolation

A design flaw in GPU drivers made by Apple, Qualcomm, AMD, and likely Imagination can be exploited by miscreants on a shared system to snoop on fellow users.…
articles.title: Apple, AMD, Qualcomm GPU security hole lets miscreants snoop on AI training and chats

articles.description:
Let's be realistic: If the EU can't regulate it well, America definitely won't

Comment  If anything could compel the US government to regulate facial-recognition technology, a report sponsored by federal law enforcement urging just that may do the trick. …
articles.title: Facial recognition tech has outpaced US law – and don't expect the Feds to catch up
